title: Apple TV films will hit cinemas weeks before their streaming debut in bid to woo Hollywood
text:
Apple will release some of the biggest films on its new streaming service exclusively in cinemas first, in what sources characterised as an effort to woo Hollywood away from Netflix.

The iPhone maker said on Friday that it would give cinema chains a free run at three of its new films, holding back their streaming debuts by up to four weeks.

People familiar with the plan told the told the Wall Street Journal that it was designed to attract prominent directors and producers to Apple TV Plus, as well as create a sense of glamour around their releases.

That would be a departure from the traditional strategy of Netflix, which has often insisted that films it owns or produces be released simultaneously on its streaming service and in cinemas, sometimes alienating cinema companies.

It comes as both companies gear up for a potentially vicious multi-sided streaming war between not only Netflix and Apple but also Amazon, Disney, the US TV network NBC and other, smaller rivals.

"The fact that there's going to be much more competition means that all these streaming services are going to have to be far more flexible in terms of how they deal with content creators," said Tom Harrington, a broadcast market analyst at Enders Analysis.
